docs.abstract: The cartel wants to take 1.5 million barrels a day off the market as the coronavirus outbreak curbs demand. But the assent of Russia and others is needed.
docs.snippet: The cartel wants to take 1.5 million barrels a day off the market as the coronavirus outbreak curbs demand. But the assent of Russia and others is needed.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries proposed Thursday that oil output be curbed by 1.5 million barrels a day, or 1.5 percent of world oil supplies, to deal with the effects of the spreading coronavirus outbreak on demand.

headline.main: OPEC Proposes a Large Cut in Oil Output
headline.print_headline: OPEC Proposes Slashing Oil Output Over Russian Resistance

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

docs.abstract: Coronavirus has sapped the world’s demand for oil, and major producers cannot agree on what to do.
docs.snippet: Coronavirus has sapped the world’s demand for oil, and major producers cannot agree on what to do.
docs.lead_paragraph: Oil prices plummeted on Friday after major producers failed to reach an agreement to reduce production, as concerns about coronavirus’s impact on the economy spread across the globe.

headline.main: Oil Prices Nose-Dive as OPEC and Russia Fail to Reach a Deal
headline.print_headline: Oil Prices Nose-Dive as Producers Can’t Agree on a Cutback

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

docs.abstract: Some who own or charter superyachts want to take them on adventures, but the risks are high and insurers are balking.
docs.snippet: Some who own or charter superyachts want to take them on adventures, but the risks are high and insurers are balking.
docs.lead_paragraph: Yachts — the mere word connotes luxury and easy living. They are a symbol of wealth second only to private jets.

headline.main: Yachts Are for More Than Lounging

docs.abstract: The virtual shutdown of one of the world’s biggest economies is hurting business around the globe, from multinational firms to truck drivers and tour guides.
docs.snippet: The virtual shutdown of one of the world’s biggest economies is hurting business around the globe, from multinational firms to truck drivers and tour guides.
docs.lead_paragraph: In an industrial area west of Chicago’s O’Hare International Airport, more than 6,000 miles from China, Michael Smerling is steeling himself for a devastating blow from the coronavirus outbreak.

headline.main: China Stopped Its Economy to Tackle Coronavirus. Now the World Suffers.
headline.print_headline: Shutdown Is Felt Around the World

docs.abstract: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
docs.snippet: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
docs.lead_paragraph: As small businesses such as restaurants, bars, gyms and hair salons are forced by the coronavirus pandemic to go dark and lay off millions of employees, frantic owners are desperate for government aid to help them salvage enterprises that can’t survive for long without customers.

headline.main: Small Businesses Seek a Crisis Lifeline Beyond Loans

byline.original: By Stacy Cowley and Tiffany Hsu

docs.abstract: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.
docs.snippet: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you were watching some of the commentators on Fox News and Fox Business in the first 10 days of March, you wouldn’t have been too worried about the coronavirus — it would be no worse than the flu, and the real story was the “coronavirus impeachment scam.”

headline.main: As Fox News Played Down the Coronavirus, Its Chief Protected Himself
headline.print_headline: As Fox News Discounted Virus, Its Chief Was Protected

docs.abstract: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
docs.snippet: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.

headline.main: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
headline.print_headline: How Fox Got the Virus So Wrong: Start With Its C.E.O.
